block.p: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

KANE ALEXANDER, Firebird Cafe, 363 West 46th Street, Clinton, (212) 586-0244. This fresh-faced 23-year-old Australian, an alumnus of a homegrown production of ''Les Miserables,'' is a poised, charming, raven-haired Ken doll with a real singing voice. A protege of Les Solomon, the same impresario who introduced David Campbell, Mr. Alexander blends American and Australian show tunes into an autobiographical odyssey that carries him from a tiny village in the Outback to New York City. As ingenuous as he may appear, his interpretations are tasteful and intelligently conceived. Tomorrow at 9 and 11 p.m. Cover: $25; $15 minimum. Also at the Firebird, tonight at 9, David Gurland, singer; at 11, Chris Coleman, singer. Cover: $20; $15 minimum.
Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

KANE ALEXANDER, Firebird Cafe, 363 West 46th Street, Clinton, (212) 586-0244. This fresh-faced 23-year-old Australian, an alumnus of a homegrown production of ''Les Miserables,'' is a poised, charming, raven-haired Ken doll with a real singing voice. A protege of Les Solomon, the same impresario who introduced David Campbell, Mr. Alexander blends American and Australian show tunes into an autobiographical odyssey that carries him from a tiny village in the Outback to New York City. As ingenuous as he may appear, his interpretations are tasteful and intelligently conceived. Tomorrow at 9 and 11 p.m. Cover: $25; $15 minimum. Also at the Firebird, tonight at 9, David Gurland, singer; at 11, Chris Coleman, singer. Cover: $20; $15 minimum.

BARBARA CARROLL, Bemelmans Bar, Carlyle Hotel, 35 East 76th Street, (212) 744-1600. This agelessly chic red-haired pianist and singer seems to know every important popular song ever written and to be able to perform from memory in any key. Her elegant, lyrical pianism is a compendium of 20th-century jazz styles, from Count Basie to Erroll Garner to Bill Evans and beyond. And her clipped, understated vocals, which verge on speech-song, approach lyrics from a wry but warmhearted point of view. Through July 22. Tuesday through Saturday nights, beginning at 9:30. From 5:30 to 8, Michael Devine. No cover for early show; cover for late show: $15. No minimum; $5 cover at the bar.

* HOWARD FISHMAN QUARTET, Sardi's, 234 West 44th Street, (212) 221-8440. Powerful echoes of Stephane Grappelli and Bix Beiderbecke are among the influences rippling through the Howard Fishman Quartet's seamless swing. The group -- Mr. Fishman on guitar, banjo and vocals; Russell Farhang playing virtuosic Grappelli-style violin; Peter Ecklund on cornet; Andrew Hall on bass -- folds elements of vintage jazz, swing and early bluegrass into rhythmically animated, richly allusive jazz chamber music. Whether the music is Stephen Foster (a bubbly ''Old Folks at Home''), Gershwin (''Soon'') or Romberg (''When I Grow Too Old to Dream''), it is all translated into lilting, fine-tuned ensemble music that transcends time and idiom. Fridays at 10:30 p.m. No cover charge, but $15 minimum at tables.

* ''OUR SINATRA,'' Blue Angel Theater, 323 West 44th Street, Clinton, (212) 239-6200. The rising young cabaret star Eric Comstock is the mastermind behind this utterly winning tribute to Ol' Blue Eyes, which focuses on what Mr. Comstock calls the hidden gems and orphan songs that Sinatra made popular. Joined by Christopher Gines, a creamy baritone who echoes Dick Haymes and Steve Lawrence in their prime, and Hilary Kole, a perky swinger, Mr. Comstock conducts a witty and knowledgeable survey of the Sinatra canon. Mr. Comstock concentrates on the mature Sinatra and Mr. Gines on the dreamy 1940's balladeer, with Ms. Kole bridging the gap. The memorable show proves that there are still young singers good enough to keep the tradition alive. Tonight, tomorrow, Monday and Thursday at 8 p.m.; Sunday at 3 and 7:30 p.m.; Wednesday at 2:30 and 8 p.m. Tickets: $50 and $55 (premium ringside seating, $75 and $80).

ARCI'S PLACE, 450 Park Avenue South, at 30th Street, (212) 532-4370. Tom Postilio, singer, in ''This Time Around,'' directed by Thommie Walsh. Tonight and tomorrow night at 9. Cover: $25; $15 minimum.

DANNY'S SKYLIGHT ROOM, 346 West 46th Street, Clinton, (212) 265-8133. Tonight at 7, Tom Thomsen Improv Group in ''Actors in Search of a Script''; from 9 to 1 in the piano bar, Jerry Scott. Tomorrow night from 5 to 9 p.m. in the piano bar, Chuck Musone; from 9 to 1 in the piano bar, Mr. Scott. Sunday night from 7 to 11, Sol Yaged and friends. Cover: free to $15; $10 minimum.

DON'T TELL MAMA, 343 West 46th Street, Clinton, (212) 757-0788. Tonight at 7, Barbie Anderson, singer; also at 7, Danielle Stewart, singer, with Stephen Cornine, pianist; at 9, ''Poole Party!,'' comedy, with Ron Poole; also at 9, Lisa Asher, singer, with Jeff Waxman, pianist; at 11, ''The Stand-Up Comedy Experience.'' Tomorrow night at 9, Gay and Lesbian Stand-Up and Musical Comedy Festival; at 10:30, ''Poole Party!'' Cover: Free to $18. Two-drink minimum. No credit cards.
DUPLEX, 61 Christopher Street, at Seventh Avenue South, West Village, (212) 255-5438. Tonight at 10, ''The Grodin Show,'' comedy. Cover: $6 plus two-drink minimum. No credit cards.

FEINSTEIN'S, at the Regency, 540 Park Avenue, at 61st Street, (212) 339-4095. Marc Salem. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8:30 and 11; Tuesdays through Thursday nights at 8:30. Cover: $60; dinner required for early show, with seating beginning at 6; a la carte supper menu with $25 minimum for late show. Through Sept. 2.

JOE'S PUB, Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, East Village, (212) 539-8778 or (212) 239-6200. Tomorrow night at 8:30, Flying Neutrinos, New Orleans-style rhythm and horns quintet, with vocals. Sunday night at 9, Kelli Sae, singer-songwriter. Tickets: $15.

JUDY'S CHELSEA, 169 Eighth Avenue, at 18th Street, (212) 929-5410. Tonight at 8:30, Effie Jansen, singer, and her trio in ''Totally Effie.'' Monday night at 8:30, Robert Anton, singer, and Wan Chuan Kao, pianist. Cover: $10 to $20; $10 minimum.

OAK ROOM, Algonquin Hotel, 59 West 44th Street, (212) 840-6800. Julie Budd. Tonight and tomorrow night at 9 and 11; Tuesday through Thursday nights at 9. Cover: $40, with dinner required for early shows Fridays and Saturdays; $15 food or drink minimum for other shows; suggested dinner arrival for early show is 7. Through July 8.

SUPPER CLUB, 240 West 47th Street, (212) 921-1940. Tonight and tomorrow night from 8 to midnight, the Supper Club's 17-piece big band. Also, the 25-minute swing revue ''This Joint Is Jumpin' '' on Fridays and Saturdays at 9:30 and 10:30 P.M., with Larry Marshall. Swing dance lessons every Friday and Saturday night from 11:15 to midnight in the Blue Room. Tonight, Nick Palumbo and the Flipped Fedoras; tomorrow night, Jet Set Six, performances from 12:30 to 2:30 a.m. Cover: $25 before 11, $15 after.

TRIAD, 158 West 72nd Street, (212) 362-2590. Tonight at 8, Lee Truesdale, singer; at 8:30 in the lounge, ''M,'' singer; at 10, ''Oz Noy and Friends,'' featuring Oz, Jeff Kazee, Joel Rosenblatt and Mike Duclos. Tomorrow from midnight, upstairs, comics from Def Jam, B.E.T. and HBO. Cover: $5 to $15; two-drink minimum.

UPSTAIRS AT ROSE'S TURN, 55 Grove Street, West Village, (212) 366-5438. Tonight at 7, ''Me, Him, Her and the Other Guy,'' sketch comedy; at 9, ''The Elephant Man: The Musical,'' musical comedy; at 11, ''Candy Comedy Hour.'' Cover: $5 to $7; two-drink minimum. No credit cards.
